statement:
Suppose $X,Y,Z$ are topological spaces, $f\colon X\to Y$ is a bijective
proper map, and $g\colon Y\to Z$ is a coercive map. Then
$g\circ f\colon X\to Z$ is a coercive map.

Let $J\subseteq Z$ be a compact set. As $g$ is coercive, there is a
compact set $K\subseteq Y$ such that
$$g(Y\setminus K) \subseteq Z\setminus J.$$ Let $I=f^{-1}(K)$, and since
$f$ is a proper map $I$ is compact. Thus
$$(g\circ f) (X\setminus I) = g(Y\setminus K) \subseteq Z\setminus J$$
and $g\circ f$ is coercive.
